scientific_summary: Anger subsides with physiological cooling, cognitive reappraisal, and assertive communication skills (Novaco, 2011).

immediate.title: Cold hold reset
instructions: Hold a cool pack or rinse wrists under cold water for 30 seconds.
While cooling, breathe in for 4 counts and out for 6 counts.
Repeat three times, lowering shoulders each cycle.

evidence.summary: Temperature shifts activate the dive reflex and quickly reduce anger-driven arousal.

immediate.title: Box breathing
instructions: Inhale through the nose for 4 counts.
Hold lungs full for 4 counts, softening the jaw.
Exhale for 4 counts, hold empty for 4, and repeat for 6 cycles.

evidence.source: Seppälä et al., Frontiers in Psychology, 2014
evidence.summary: Box breathing lowers sympathetic arousal and improves emotion regulation.

short_term.title: Anger thought log
instructions: Write the triggering event and the automatic thought ('They never listen').
Identify the need or value underneath (respect, fairness).
Draft a balanced statement that acknowledges both feelings and facts.

evidence.summary: Cognitive restructuring reduces anger intensity by challenging distorted appraisals.

short_term.title: Assertive communication script
instructions: Use the 'I feel… when… because… I need…' format to script your message.
Practice saying it aloud with a calm tone.
Plan the best time to deliver it when emotions have cooled.

evidence.summary: Assertive expression decreases anger recurrence and improves conflict outcomes.

long_term.title: Regular cardiovascular routine
instructions: Schedule moderate aerobic activity (walk, cycle) three times weekly.
During movement, focus on exhalations and releasing tension.
Track mood before and after to notice reductions in baseline anger.

evidence.source: Lox et al., Psychology of Physical Activity, 2014
evidence.summary: Regular aerobic exercise lowers anger and hostility markers over time.

long_term.title: Loving-kindness practice
instructions: Sit comfortably and repeat phrases of goodwill for yourself ('May I be safe, calm').
Extend the phrases to someone neutral, then to the person who sparked anger when ready.
End by acknowledging your own need for safety and respect.

evidence.summary: Loving-kindness meditation increases positive regard and reduces anger and implicit bias.

friend_support.title: Co-regulate through active listening
instructions: Sit or stand at eye level with your friend and keep your posture relaxed.
Reflect back the core feeling you hear ("It sounds like you felt dismissed when that happened").
Validate their experience without problem-solving until they confirm they feel understood.

evidence.source: Kouros et al., Journal of Family Psychology, 2021
evidence.summary: Accurate emotional validation from close others reduces anger persistence and supports physiological regulation.

friend_support.title: Create a two-step cooling plan together
instructions: Ask your friend which body-based reset helps (walk, cold water, paced breath) and agree to do it alongside them.
Schedule a check-in after 20 minutes to debrief once arousal has dropped.
End by summarizing the shared next step to prevent the trigger again.

evidence.source: American Psychological Association Anger Management Guidelines, 2020
evidence.summary: Collaborative coping plans lower relapse of anger episodes and increase perceptions of support.

self_repair.title: Use the 4-part repair script
instructions: Name the behavior without excuses ("I raised my voice and interrupted you").
Acknowledge the impact on them ("That left you feeling disrespected").
State the regulation skill you will use next time (paced breathing before responding).
Invite feedback and agree on a follow-up check-in within 24 hours.

evidence.source: Finkel et al., Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 2014
evidence.summary: Structured apologies that include impact acknowledgment and concrete repair steps improve forgiveness and relationship satisfaction.

self_repair.title: Run a trigger reflection grid
instructions: Draw a 2x2 grid and label rows 'What I Felt' and 'What I Needed'.
Label columns 'Before I reacted' and 'After I reacted'.
Fill the boxes, then identify one boundary or request that would meet the unmet need without escalation.
Share the request with the other person once both of you are calm.

evidence.source: Navarro-Haro et al., Behaviour Research and Therapy, 2018
evidence.summary: Structured cognitive reviews reduce anger rumination and support adaptive boundary-setting.
